title: Genetically modified mosquitoes successfully passed their first test in the US
description: The first US trial of genetically modified mosquitoes is so far a success. Researchers studied the outcomes of their experiment by collecting mosquito eggs.
content: Back in August of 2020, authorities in Florida received the green light from the Environment Protection Agency for a pilot project that saw 750 million genetically modified mosquitoes released in the Florida Keys between 2021 and 2022. The project wa... [1992 chars]

title: Adherence to Mediterranean-Style Diet May Cut Preeclampsia Risk
description: Odds of preeclampsia lower with greatest level of adherence to Mediterranean-style diet; similar benefit observed for Black women
content: WEDNESDAY, April 20, 2022 (HealthDay News) -- Adherence to a Mediterranean-style diet is associated with reduced odds of preeclampsia, according to a study published online April 20 in the Journal of the American Heart Association. Anum S. Minhas, M.... [1515 chars]

title: Biomarkers May Help Guide Treatment in Cancer Patients With COVID-19
description: A systematic review has revealed biomarkers that may provide prognostic insight and guide treatment in patients with cancer and COVID-19.

title: Cardiovascular Disease, Mortality Higher With Serious Mental Illness
description: Association stronger in most recent decades and among those with schizophrenia
content: WEDNESDAY, April 20, 2022 (HealthDay News) -- People with serious mental illness (SMI), particularly schizophrenia, have higher levels of cardiovascular disease (CVD)-related mortality and a higher incidence of CVD than the general population, accord... [1676 chars]

title: Could NSAIDs Negate Bisphosphonate Benefits?
description: Women taking clodronate and NSAIDs didn't see a protective effect
content: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) seemed to neutralize the protective benefit of a certain bisphosphonate, according to a post-hoc analysis of a randomized controlled trial. Among over 5,200 community-dwelling women ages 75 and older, tho... [3589 chars]

title: 5 Ways to Shrink Visceral Fat While Eating Breakfast, Say Dietitians
description: If you're trying to shrink visceral fat, here are five strategies to implement when eating breakfast in the morning.
content: Trying to plan the perfect breakfast is easier said than done, especially when you want to burn fat. According to Johns Hopkins Medicine, dieters should try to target visceral fat, which builds up around your abdominal cavity and correlates to higher... [4269 chars]

title: Best Breakfast Habits for a Healthy Gut, Say Dietitians
description: Start your morning off on the right foot with best breakfast habits for a healthy gut. These habits will keep your gut happy and healthy.
content: An unhealthy gut means that your digestive system is unable to process food properly, which could lead to digestive issues such as gas, bloating, and abdominal pain. Your immune system can also become weak due to a lack of bacteria in the gut, potent... [6410 chars]

title: 30 percent of people catching the virus get it
description: Researchers studied patients at a single institution to minimize the variation in medical care. But Medicaid patients were less likely to get Long COVID.
content: After studying over 1,000 patients infected with COVID-19, researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles, (UCLA) found that about 30 percent develop Post Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC), or Long COVID, as it is more commonly known. As th... [2617 chars]

title: Investigating the impact of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron spike mutations
description: Researchers investigated the impact of amino acid substitutions of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron on spike protein function, processing, and neutralization susceptibility.
content: In a recent study posted to the bioRxiv* preprint server, researchers investigated the impact of amino acid (AA) substitutions of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) Omicron on spike (S) protein function, processing, and neut... [5423 chars]

title: Black lung cases increasing among US coal miners
description: Researchers found higher levels of silica dust in the lung tissue of contemporary coal miners compared to the lung tissue of previous generations of coal miners.
content: The study points out that from 1970 to 2005, the rate of black lung cases among coal miners had been declining, largely due to improved occupational health practices required by federal regulations. However, since 2005, black lung cases, in general, ... [1950 chars]
